A line segment, when translated at a 45-degree angle, will intersect its original position exactly once. Imagine sliding a ruler diagonally; it crosses its original path only at one point.
A translated line segment will be parallel to the original segment. Parallel lines never intersect.
A line segment translated along a direction that is not parallel to it will never intersect the original line segment.
When a line segment is translated at an angle, it will intersect the original segment twice. Imagine sliding a ruler diagonally across another ruler - they cross twice.
A slanted line segment translated vertically will continuously overlap with its original position, resulting in an infinite number of intersections.
When a line segment is translated horizontally, it maintains the same slope and only shifts its position.  Therefore, it will never intersect with its original position.
A line segment translated perpendicular to itself will never intersect its original position. Imagine sliding a ruler straight up or down - it won't cross over where it started.
Translating a line segment vertically and connecting it to the original creates two parallel sides and two non-parallel sides, which is the definition of a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment downward and connecting it to the original creates two parallel sides and two perpendicular sides, forming a rectangle.
Shifting a line segment to the upper left and connecting it to the original creates a parallelogram. The opposite sides will be parallel.
Translating a line segment to the left creates a parallel line. Connecting the original and translated segments forms a parallelogram.
Translating a line segment upward creates a parallel line. Connecting the original and translated segments forms a trapezoid, a quadrilateral with one pair of parallel sides.
Translating a line segment downward creates a second parallel line. Connecting the endpoints forms a trapezoid, a quadrilateral with one pair of parallel sides.
Translating the line segment to the left and connecting it to the original creates two sides and a base, forming a triangle.
Shifting a line segment up and to the left by its own length creates a parallelogram. The opposite sides will be parallel and equal in length.
Translating a line segment upward and then to the right creates a second line segment parallel to the original. Connecting the endpoints forms a parallelogram.
Translating a line segment upward and then to the left creates a second line segment parallel to the original. Connecting the endpoints forms a parallelogram.
Rotating the arrow 180 degrees clockwise will reverse its direction, making the arrowhead point South.
Rotating an arrow 180 degrees clockwise will reverse its direction. If it initially points east, it will point west after the rotation.
Rotating a south-pointing arrow 90 degrees clockwise results in it pointing east.
A 270-degree counterclockwise rotation from a rightward direction results in an upward direction.
Rotating a leftward pointing ray 90 degrees clockwise results in an upward pointing ray.
Rotating a downward ray 90 degrees counterclockwise results in a ray pointing to the right.
Rotating a ray 180 degrees clockwise reverses its direction. If it initially pointed right, it will point left after the rotation.
Rotating a leftward pointing ray 90 degrees counterclockwise results in an upward pointing ray.
Rotating a ray 270 degrees clockwise around its endpoint results in a ray that is perpendicular to the original ray.
Rotating a line 45 degrees around a point on the line will bring it back to its original position, making it coincident with the original line.
Rotating a line segment 180 degrees around one endpoint will cause it to overlap perfectly with its original position.
Compressing the left half towards the right will shift the overall midpoint of the line segment to the right.
When the right half is compressed, the overall length of the line segment decreases. Since the left half remains unchanged, the midpoint will shift towards the left.
Compressing both sides of a line segment towards the center will maintain the position of the midpoint.
Compressing a line segment upward maintains the relative position of its midpoint.
Compressing a ray horizontally makes it steeper, which means it becomes more horizontal relative to the original ray.
Compressing a line segment from both ends towards the center maintains the position of the midpoint.
Stretching the left half to the left will shift the entire midpoint of the line segment towards the left.
Stretching the right half of the line segment to the right will shift the overall midpoint of the line segment to the right.
Stretching both sides of the line segment equally will not change the position of the midpoint. The midpoint remains the same distance from both ends.
Folding a line segment at its midpoint causes the two ends to overlap, resulting in a single point.
Folding a line segment at its midpoint and unfolding it creates an angle where the two halves meet.

When you fold a line segment to form an isosceles right triangle, the hypotenuse is the original line segment.  The two legs of an isosceles right triangle are congruent and have a length of √2/2 times the length of the hypotenuse.
When you fold a line segment to form an equilateral triangle, you divide the original line segment into two equal parts, which become the sides of the triangle.

When you fold a line segment in half to form two sides of an equilateral triangle, you are essentially dividing the original line segment into two equal parts. Each of these parts becomes a side of the equilateral triangle.
When you fold a line segment to form a square, you are dividing the original line segment into four equal parts, each representing one side of the square.
When you fold a line segment to form three sides of a square, you are essentially dividing the original line segment into two equal parts. Each of these parts then becomes a side of the square.
When you fold a line segment to form two sides of a square, you are essentially dividing the original line segment into two equal parts, which become the sides of the square.
Rotating a right-angled triangle 180 degrees around its right angle vertex will result in the hypotenuse pointing in the same direction as before the rotation.

Rotating a triangle 180 degrees around its right angle will result in the hypotenuse pointing in the opposite direction, but since it's a 180-degree rotation, it will end up pointing in the same original direction.

Rotating a right-angled triangle 90 degrees counterclockwise around its right angle will not change the direction of the hypotenuse. The hypotenuse will still be the longest side opposite the right angle.
